ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I believe I became a better writer. Reading German literature also helped me parse texts to understand their message and intent.

A really good knowledge of the first three books in A Song of Ice and Fire/getting absolutely hooked on them. For the theoretical side, we studied early theories of sovereignty (Machiavelli, Bodin, Hobbes), and then moved into German theory of modern iterations of sovereignty and the exception (Schmitt, Weber, Agamben) and literary form (Jolles, Benjamin).  All this came together in class discussions where we applied the theories and discussed broader themes of the book.
In this class, I was able to closely read and critique the A Song of Ice and Fire series, discussing the themes of sovereignty and power within the complex world of Westeros.
This course strengthened my literary analysis and writing skills. It also taught me more about political philosophy and its applications on a work of fiction.
political theory and german political philosophy
Quick read of GoT, theory readings on sovereignty and how GoT is written
I learned a lot about philosophy and history that contributed to Martin's writing of A song of Ice and Fire.

I was able to read about a subject that I loved and everyone else was equally invested in while applying that to political theory that as a STEM major I had not spent much time reading. The political philosophy readings were interesting and out of the ordinary. Only one of the authors was someone that I had read before so it was incredibly interesting!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The discussions in this course were great. I really enjoyed this class. Maybe an improvement could be before a difficult reading we could lay out some context to better understand it, as I definitely found some readings confusing.

This class was awesome. The A Song of Ice and Fire were amazing, and our discussions on them were always interesting and thought provoking. The theoretical readings could be tough at times, but they were a valuable component of the class and really lent valuable context to the story and lenses through which we could view it. My one suggestion would be that the introductions/introductory presentations could be a bit long or dry at times, but they were usually helpful and class always picked up once we moved into discussion.

I think the discussion based format of the course was extremely engaging, and led to  really interesting ideas being shared throughout class. However, I felt that the course had too many readings, and would have from more theoretical readings and also maybe even a watching of video essays or the Game of Thrones HBO series.

This course was fantastic! The professor, TF, and other students were all very engaging and the subject material was so much fun to discuss! The readings may seem overwhelming at first, but they are achievable and the pace at which the class clipped along felt just right.
The reading load was a bit high
The course was very well-organized and both Professor Wetters and Benjamin provided a great deal of feedback on papers!
great course, I think reading Hannah Arendt could add some interest to the course.
really awesome material. the 9am start time was suboptimal though.
Sometimes the seminar format over zoom was a little stilted, but the readings were very interesting

Strengths: the Material, professor wetters is excellent
Weaknesses: just the time and like how it was on zoom. nothing that could have been controlled by the professor or anything.

Really just a great class such interesting material.

great content and great professor. the syllabus lacked readings from women and POC, and gave undue focus on philosophers who have Nazi ties. I wish we had spent less time on Schmitt, Jolles, etc. and more time bringing in Hannah Arendt and others

This course is awesome! It was the best course I took all semester and I absolutely loved the topic and the teaching style. Professor Wetters is incredibly helpful, interesting and does not dominate the conversation (very interactive). The only issue may have been the quantity of reading, however that was a bit of an unavoidable problem considering the books we had to get through.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: For a Zoom class, this went pretty well. Essentially all of the work came from reading, which is still easy to do without in-person events.
Breakout rooms were a nice aspect enabled by the virtual format, I really appreciated being able to go in depth with that smaller group setting.

I thought the discussions in class still flowed very well even through the online format of the class. I think this was due to the student presentations and the student-led discussions, which made conversation more natural. Plus, both Prof. Wetters and Benjamin were extremely kind and knowledgable of the material, and it was extremely easy to set up a discussion or create an email chain with both of them.
The course could have used break out rooms a bit more to facilitate discussion, however class-wide discussion also worked quite well!
not sure
Zoom seminars = not very engaged discussions
The breakout rooms really helped. It was nice to talk in a small group with others and get to know them.
They were really really accomodating during this difficult time which I appreciated. I wish more professors were as understanding as Professor Wetters.

I thought that the small breakout rooms were most effective! Since this was a seminar the format was already better for zoom than a lecture but smaller discussions are always better for conversation I have found on zoom. Would have been wonderful as an in-person seminar but this was one of the better courses overall given the format.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you like Game of Thrones or want to read the books, I very much recommend.

Absolutely. First of all, it does not matter how much you know about the show or the books. I came into this class having only read the first book and seeing exactly none of the TV show, some students had read all the books and seen the whole show, and some came in completely blind, but everyone brought valuable perspectives and insights to the class. Second, the weekly homework was a theoretical reading and ~200 pages of the series. The theory reading were sometimes tough but usually interesting, and the books were literally pleasure reading that we got super into. The larger assignments were a couple papers and a presentation, and the feedback on all of them was some of the best I've ever gotten. Third, class itself was interesting and lively despite being a 9 a.m., and the group of people we had was an awesome mix  Fourth, Professor Wetters and Benjamin were great--super knowledgeable, but also considerate and kind. All in all, amazing class. If you get the chance, take it.

Yes! I would definitely recommend this course to any and all students interested in reading A Song of Ice and Fire. It's kind of crazy realizing how many themes of power exist within the A Song of Ice and Fire Universe, and discussing this piece of fiction in this academic context is eye-opening and mind-blowing. Plus, Professor Wetters is extremely caring and knowledgable

Yes! This course is a great opportunity to read Game of Thrones and have fun analyzing it with other students. If you are interested in political theory and philosohy (as well as fantasy books), then this course is definitely for you!
Yes! Very interesting course and class discussions were very engaging. Kirk is a phenomenal prof
Yes!! The course was very interesting and a great way to learn about a variety of topics through the lens of Game of Thrones.
yes, would highly recommend, very fun and engaging course
It's a lot of reading but a really cool course.
Yes, opportunities to close-read a popular, modern fiction series are rare, and you will also learn German political philosophy as well. This is an incredibly unique course!
Yes, I would recommend it. Even though it is quite a bit of work the material is interesting and Professor Wetters is amazing
Yes

YES this was an amazing course. It was fun and interesting and allowed students to nerd out a little bit about game of thrones while learning the political intricacies of (mostly) German political philosophy. It was the perfect course to take as a Senior and really capped off my Yale experience. I am so glad that I took this and cannot recommend it enough. Professor Wetters is interesting and helpful. The feedback was always incredible, and both professor and TA were always available to help and give feedback. The course was very accommodating and really made the reading and discussion experience enjoyable for all of the students. PLEASE TAKE THIS IF YOU CAN.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
n/a
breakout rooms and student presentations along with seminar discussion
